A 'turkey' is a large bird in the genus 'Meleagris'. One species, [[Meleagris
gallopavo]] (commonly known as the Wild Turkey) is native to the forests of
North America. The domestic turkey is a descendant of this species. The other
living species is [[Meleagris ocellata]] or the Ocellated Turkey, native to the
forests of the YucatÃ¡n Peninsula.

Turkeys are classed in the taxonomic order of Galliformes. Within this order
they are relatives of the grouse family or subfamily. Males of both species have
a distinctive fleshy wattle or protuberance that hangs from the top of the beak
(called a snood in the Wild Turkey and its domestic descendants). They are among
the largest birds in their ranges. As in many galliformes, the male (tom or
gobbler) is larger and much more colorful than the female (hen). Genus Meleagris
is the only genus in the subfamily 'Meleagridinae', formerly known as the family
'Meleagrididae', but now subsumed within the family Phasianidae.
